As for the\ngroup of countries on which we focus our scenario analysis, the HAC generates a tight de-\npendence between systematic factors for Greek, Italian and Portuguese credit exposures.\nInterestingly, credit losses in Spain are more closely related to the group of countries we\ndescribed \u010f\u0179rst. Between both groups, no considerable dependence can be detected.\n\nThe combination of the univariate gamma marginal distributions and the hierarchical\nGumbel-copula makes up the joint M -dimensional distribution function of the systematic\nfactors. This completes our de\u010f\u0179nition of the dependence structure in the proposed port-\nfolio model. What remains to be described is the link between the portfolio model and\nthe macroeconomic scenarios.\n\n\n6.3 The link between NPL ratio projections and the portfolio\n\nmodel\n\nTo embed the portfolio model SystemicCreditRisk into the stress testing framework, we\nperform a percentile mapping between the NPL ratios and the systematic factors that\nwill conduct the e\u010f\u0179ect of macroeconomic projections to the borrower PDs.39 For this\npurpose, we \u010f\u0179rst \u010f\u0179t gamma distributions to the country-speci\u010f\u0179c observations of the NPL\nratios (similarly to the procedure applied for the systematic factors). Then, given a\nrealization of the NPL ratio for a country in a macro scenario, we calculate to which\npercentile of the \u010f\u0179tted gamma distribution this realization corresponds. This percentile\nserves in the following simulation as the lower threshold for the systematic factor(s) for\nthis country. Conditioning on the percentiles means that acceptable realizations of the\nsystematic factors can only lie above the speci\u010f\u0179ed thresholds. Thus, sampled systematic\nfactors cannot be \u00e2better\u00e2 than suggested by the scenario, but they can be \u00e2worse\u00e2. The\npercentile mapping is done for those 28 countries for which NPL ratio projections are\navailable.40 Even if no percentile mapping is possible for the remaining \u010f\u0179ve countries and\ngeographic regions, the corresponding sampled systematic factors will depend on stress\nscenarios, too. The reason for this is that realizations of all systematic factors have to\nexceed their respective thresholds simultaneously. This constrains the area of the HAC\nfrom which sampling is performed. That is, all systematic factors are sampled from a\nsmall, \u00e2stressed\u00e2 part of the copula.\n\nFigure A.8 illustrates the percentiles of the estimated gamma distributions that cor-\nrespond to NPL ratio projections per country in each scenario. For countries such as\nFrance, Netherlands or Germany, where historical NPL ratios over the observation period\nwere not very high, the stressed, large values of NPL ratios lie in the far right tail of the\ndistribution. That is, they represent rare events for these countries. By contrast, for GIPS\ncountries with a historic record of high NPL ratios, realizations from stress scenarios seem\nto be more commonplace, so the NPL ratio percentiles are lower.\n\n6.4 Simulation of portfolio losses\n\nThe NPL ratio projections determine from which part of the estimated copula systematic\nfactors can be drawn. The sampled simulated factors will a\u010f\u0179ect borrower PDs and,\nultimately, the distribution of credit portfolio losses in accordance with the simulation\nprocedure described in Section 2.3.\n\nFor our simulation study, we use the data from the credit register as of the end of\n2013 and assume a static balance sheet. Thus, we sample portfolio losses (PL) quarter-\nby-quarter, scenario after scenario based on the same portfolio composition. The time\n\n39A direct link between the macro model and the portfolio model is problematic. On the one hand,\nNPL ratios are not reported in the credit register. On the other hand, there is no breakdown of NPL\nratios by sector in Germany. Similarly, the data on NPL ratios covers only a limited sub-sample of\ncountries reported in the credit register.\n\n40In Germany, one country-speci\u010f\u0179c percentile threshold applies to all domestic sectors.\nrealization of all stress scenarios coincides with the baseline, however. Therefore, for the stress scenarios,\n\n\nFirst, we draw joint realizations of the 69 systematic factors using their constrained\ncopula. The resulting sample only contains realizations that lie above the \u00e2stressed\u00e2 NPL\nratio thresholds. Figure A.9 demonstrates the magnitude of the systematic factors in the\noil crisis scenario for a number of selected sectors and countries. The systematic factors\nscale up PDs for the borrowers in Italy, Greece and Portugal as high as by a factor of\napproximately 3 to 4. For Spain and, for instance, the United Kingdom, the scaling\nfactors of around 2 apply. The same is true of the German real estate sector (excluding\nhousing companies) and the banking sector. For other domestic \u010f\u0179nancial intermediaries,\nthe oil crisis scenario a\u010f\u0179ects only a moderate increase in PDs of some 50%. Similar scaling\nfactors apply to French borrowers\u00e2 PDs.\n\nIn the next simulation step, we draw default indicators for all borrowers using PDs\nconditional on a realization of systematic factors and calculate the banks\u00e2 portfolio losses.\nFigure A.10 shows a few examples of PL distributions after performing ten million sim-\nulation runs. Comparing PL distribution under the baseline and the oil crisis scenario,\nwe see that not only the magnitude of simulated losses but also sometimes the shape of\ndistribution change considerably under the stress scenario, shifting both bank portfolios\nand the system\u00e2s portfolios into a more dangerous area of high credit risk.\n\nBased on the sampled distribution, we calculate relevant risk measures as described\nat the end of Section 2.3. For the simulations under the baseline and stress scenarios we\nfocus on the system-wide tail risk represented by the system\u00e2s ES. In order to calculate\nthe system\u00e2s ES, we \u010f\u0179x the percentile threshold at a lower of q = 99%, which accounts in\na non-formal way for a limited probability of scenario occurrence.42\n\nFor the purpose of policy application introduced in the next section, we additionally\ncompute the banks\u00e2 individual EL and VaR based on an unconditional simulation of\ncredit portfolio losses, i.e. without regard to any macroeconomic scenarios or NPL ratio\nprojections. This means that the area of the copula, from which systematic factors are\nsampled, is not constrained by any percentile conditions; we draw realizations from the\nentire HAC.43 Running the unconditional simulation for individual banks, we take the\nregulatory threshold for credit-VaR calculation given as q = 99.9%.44\n\nBoth scenario-based and unconditional risk metrics described above can be utilized\n(alongside other supervisory information and risk assessment results) for assessing micro-\nand macroprudential capital needs, as the next section describes. In contrast to a mere\nstand-alone risk assessment for every single bank, this approach incorporates a systemic\nview of capital adequacy.\n\n42In this context, q re\u010f\u0179ects the regulator\u00e2s tolerance towards the probability of a systemic event, as\nIn our case, the latter is given by 100 \u00e2 q = 1%\npointed out by Puzanova and D\u00c2\u00a8ullmann (2013).\nconditional on a scenario. Why use ES and not VaR at the system\u00e2s level? Consider that VaR only\nrepresents minimum loss in the worst (100\u00e2 q)% of cases. Thus, it might be an appropriate risk measure\nfrom the bank owners\u00e2 point of view because their liability given the bank\u00e2s default is limited. The\nregulator, however, has to care about the losses that a bank failure may incur, i.e. in formal terms, the\nexpected losses given that the losses exceed the VaR threshold. This is exactly the de\u010f\u0179nition of ES that\nrepresents expected loss in the worst (100 \u00e2 q)% of cases. Therefore, ES is a more appropriate measure\nof externalities than VaR.\n\n43To ensure a better coverage of the entire copula (as opposed to only a small part of the copula\nconditional on NPL ratio scenarios), we increase the number of joint drawings of the systematic factors\nby factor 10 (10,000 drawings). In turn, we reduce the number of simulation runs for default indicators\nby the same factor (1,000 drawings) to ensure that the sampling remains computationally feasible.\n44This means that the regulator tolerates a bank\u00e2s unconditional probability of default of 100\u00e2q = 0.1%.\n\n\n7 Results and Policy Applications\n\n7.1 Overall assessment\n\nThis section presents an overall assessment of the capability of the system as a whole to\nwithstand severe macroeconomic shocks. Figure A.11 summarizes the results obtained\nfor the system\u00e2s portfolio that consists of all credit exposures of the 12 banks. It presents\nEL and ES at the system level calculated under the unconditional and scenario-based\nsimulations using the SystemicCreditRisk model. These risk metrics suggest that, if we\nonly consider shocks to the banks\u00e2 credit portfolios, the system\u00e2s ES in the unconditional\nsimulation amounts to no more than 13% of the aggregated credit RWA and 62% of the\naggregate common equity tier 1 (CET1) of the 12 banks. In the scenario analysis, the\nsystem\u00e2s ES never exceeds 18% of the reported credit RWA or 88% of the available CET1\ncapital. Thus, in aggregate, there is seemingly enough capital to support the system\u00e2s tail\ncredit risk.\n\nBut the heterogenous results at the bank level presented below tend to tell another\nstory. Although a number of banks appear very well capitalized to withstand even the\nmaximum stress imposed by the scenarios, other banks\u00e2 capital level might need im-\nprovement in order to su\u010f\u0179ciently re\u010f\u0179ect tail risk externality. This indicates that the\ndistribution of capital in the banking system is not necessarily optimal from a systemic\npoint of view.45 This results remain stable also when we include more resent data from\nthe credit register for the purpose of model calibration and portfolio loss simulations.\n\n7.2 Micro- and macroprudential capital requirements\n\nThis section shows how to calibrate micro- and macroprudential capital requirements for\nindividual banks based on the risk measures provided by the model and reports model-\nbased requirements for the 12 banks under consideration.\n\nThe M-PRESS-CreditRisk framework features a holistic micro- and macroprudential\napproach to capital adequacy assessment in the banking sector. Properly adapted, it\ncan inform decisions both on CET1 capital requirements of Pillar 1 and Pillar 2 and on\nmacroprudential bu\u010f\u0179ers such as the systemic risk bu\u010f\u0179er (SRB) and the bu\u010f\u0179er for other\nsystemically important institutions (O-SII). Figure 7.1 outlines these model applications\nembedded into the overall structure of capital requirements, and the next paragraphs\nwalk us through them. Additionally, the model provides information that can be used for\nbuilding loan loss provisions in a forward-looking way.46\n\n45A reallocation of capital according to the banks\u00e2 systemic risk contributions can reduce risk in the\nbanking system, especially by decreasing the probability of multiple defaults; see Gauthier, Lehar, and\n\n46From the range of macroprudential capital tools, we omit the counter-cyclical bu\u010f\u0179er because it is\ntied, in the \u010f\u0179rst place, to aggregate credit growth; see Detken et al. (2014). On the other hand, we\ndo not consider the capital surcharge for global systemically important institutions. According to the\nBasel methodology (BCBS, 2013), setting this bu\u010f\u0179er requires detailed information on a wide range of the\nworlds\u00e2 major banks, which is not available to us. For both these instruments, Puzanova and D\u00c2\u00a8ullmann\n(2013) suggest an alternative: a credit portfolio-based approach. Another tool not considered here is the\ncapital conservation bu\u010f\u0179er. This is de\u010f\u0179ned as a \u010f\u0179xed percentage (2.5%) of an institution\u00e2s risk-weighted\nassets and, therefore, does not require any modeling.\n\n\nFigure 7.1: Model-based CET 1 capital requirements and loan loss provisions\n\nForward-looking provisioning should cover expected future losses. The model\ndeveloped in this paper suggests that a cushion against the losses expected one year ahead\nequals the unconditional expected loss of a bank, denoted in the \u010f\u0179gure as ELbank\nuncond. The\nmetric is computed as the mean of a bank\u00e2s credit portfolio loss distribution obtained\nfrom an unconditional simulation. In our example EL ranges from around 1% to roughly\n4% of the banks\u00e2 credit exposure reported in the credit register. At the aggregated level,\nit amounts to about 2% of the credit exposure of the system.\n\nThe aim of forward-looking provisioning is to absorb expected losses. Minimum capital\nrequirements and capital bu\u010f\u0179ers, on the other hand, are intended to protect individual\nbanks and the system as a whole from losses that exceed the expected amount, i.e. from\nunexpected losses. Unexpected losses are less likely to materialize, but if they do, they\ncan bring an undercapitalized institution \u00e2 or, in an extreme event, even a large part\nof the banking system \u00e2 to the brink of bankruptcy. Against this backdrop, the present\npaper focuses on addressing unexpected losses by means of both microprudential minimum\ncapital requirements and macroprudential add-ons and bu\u010f\u0179ers.\n\nMinimum capital requirements under Pillar 1 represent the minimum amount of\ncapital that a bank must have in order to cover unexpected losses at a one-year risk horizon\ncalculated in accordance with regulatory standards.\nIn general, the regulator de\u010f\u0179nes\nunexpected credit loss as the di\u010f\u0179erence between VaR (99.9% percentile) and expected\nloss computed for the credit portfolio of a bank in the unconditional simulation.\nuncond \u00e2 ELbank\n\nIn our framework, this metric corresponds to the unexpected loss at the bank-level\nobtained from the unconditional simulation and denoted as V aRbank\nuncond. Thus\ncalculated, the unexpected loss can be compared to the regulatory capital reported by a\ngiven bank. Any comparison should, however, account for di\u010f\u0179erences in the underlying\ncalculation prescriptions between the regulatory standards under Pillar 1 and our model-\nbased \u010f\u0179gures. The former is computed using either pre-de\u010f\u0179ned risk weights (standardized\napproach) or based on the assumptions of a perfectly diversi\u010f\u0179ed portfolio (internal rating-\nbased approach), which neglects credit concentration risk. In contrast, our model-based\n\n\nForward looking provisioning: ELuncondbankMinimum capital requirement: VaRuncondbank\u00e2ELuncondbank Additional Pillar 2: ESbaselinesys. contr\u00e2VaRuncondbankCapital conservation buffer Countercyclical capital buffer O-SII buffer: ESsys. share SRB: share in \u0111\u0111\u0111\u0111\u0111\u0111\u010f\u017c\u02ddESstresssys\u00e2ESbaselinesys\u010f\u017c\u02dd G-SII buffer Figure 7.2: Model-based capital requirements per bank\n\n(a) Relative to credit RWA\n\n(b) Relative to CET1\n\nNote: The \u010f\u0179gure presents the model-based capital requirements per bank as well as average values of the\nrespective capital charge for the system. According to the model-based uncon-\nditional simulations, all but one bank have enough capital to back their credit risk. The\naverage value amounts to 7% and 35%, respectively, where the average value is calculated\nas the sum over the unconditional unexpected losses of individual banks divided by the\nsum of credit RWA or of CET1 capital.\nAdditional Pillar 2 capital requirements, should cover volatility over the business\ncycle (EBA, 2014, \u00c2\u00a7358 \u010f\u0179.), i.e. risks to which a bank may expect to become exposed\n7). More generally, those risks to which an institution might be exposed beyond the coverage of Pillar 1\nrequirements should be taken into account under Pillar 2. If the risks not accounted for under Pillar 1\nare addressed by any existing capital bu\u010f\u0179er requirements, including macroprudential bu\u010f\u0179ers, Pillar 2\nrequirements should be o\u010f\u0179set against those bu\u010f\u0179ers if they address the same risk (no double charge); see\nEBA (2014, \u00c2\u00a7 346). Note, however, that di\u010f\u0179erent jurisdictions apply di\u010f\u0179erent approaches to exercising\n\n\nrelevant tail risk metric. It shows how much loss the banking system\u00e2s aggregate credit\nportfolio is expected to incur in the event that the loss exceeds the system\u00e2s VaR. The\nsupervisor should impose an additional capital charge to back this tail risk.48 For this\npurpose, the Pillar 2 capital add-on can be calculated as the banks\u00e2 contribution to the\nsystem\u00e2s ES in the baseline scenario minus the banks\u00e2 VaR from unconditional simulation\nthat was already addressed under Pillar 1: (ESsys.contr\n\nbaseline \u00e2 V aRbank\n\nuncond)+.\n\nDepending on the macroeconomic projections, the banks\u00e2 contributions to the system\u00e2s\nES expressed in euro vary over time. This gives rise to a time-varying Pillar 2 capital add-\non. Its maximum value per bank observed during the 20 quarters for which we generate\nNPL ratio projections, is shown in Figure 7.2. The add-on ranges between around 1% to\n6.5% of credit RWA or 5% to 34% of CET1 capital. The average \u010f\u0179gures come to 3% and\n\nAlthough not a macroprudential instrument per se, the Pillar 2 add-on suggested in\nthis paper takes a system-wide view on capital adequacy. This perspective is central to\nthe application of macroprudential instruments, two of which we consider in the following\nparagraphs: the SRB and the O-SII bu\u010f\u0179er.49\n\nThe systemic risk bu\u010f\u0179er is a macroprudential capital tool available to banking\nsupervisors in the EU.50 It aims at mitigating long-term non-cyclical systemic risk not\ncovered by other instruments. We argue that the SRB can be applied to ensure that even\nin a severe stress scenario the system as a whole can cover its tail risk. To guide decisions\non the possible size and timing of the bu\u010f\u0179er, we suggest using the model-based estimates of\nthe system\u00e2s ES under stress. In particular, for each of the relevant supervisory scenarios,\nthe euro amount of the system\u00e2s ES can be calculated quarter by quarter and compared\nto the system\u00e2s ES in the baseline scenario. The maximum positive di\u010f\u0179erence to the\nbaseline indicates the maximum excess systemic credit risk that should be covered by the\naggregate SRB requirement: SRBsys = max(ESsys\nbaseline)+. The capital charge\nfor each single bank equals to the amount of additional capital needed in the entire\nsystem multiplied by the bank\u00e2s average percentage share in the system\u00e2s ES: SRBbank =\nSRBsys \u00c2\u02c7 ESsys.share.51 Since the ES shares remain remarkably stable, we simply take\nthe average shares over all considered scenarios. The quarter in which the maximum\ndi\u010f\u0179erence is observed indicates the time period up to which the banks should have built\nup the bu\u010f\u0179er.\n\nstress \u00e2 ESsys\n\nIn our particular example, the oil crises scenario generates the greatest adverse impact\non the NPL ratios and portfolio loss. Therefore, the SRB is based on this scenario. It has a more\nlocal focus, and should internalize the risk which the failure of a large and interconnected\ninstitution located in the EU poses for the banking system of the EU as a whole or its\nmember states.52 According to article 131(5) of the CRD IV, O-SIIs may be required to\nmaintain an O-SII bu\u010f\u0179er of up to 2% of the RWA. In Germany, for instance, the identi\u010f\u0179ed\nO-SIIs are assigned to one of four groups with gradually decreasing bu\u010f\u0179ers of 2%, 1.5%,\n\nFollowing the currently applied methodology, we suggest an approach to how to di-\nvide the banks into the pre-de\u010f\u0179ned four buckets according to their systemic importance,\ntaking the level of the respective capital bu\u010f\u0179ers as given. We gauge the banks\u00e2 systemic\nimportance based to their mean relative share in the system\u00e2s ES, i.e. ESsys.share, and\napply the k-means clustering algorithm. This algorithm assigns banks with the largest\nESsys.share into Group 1. The other groups follow as shown in Figure 7.3.54\n\nThe sum of all capital requirements suggested by our model at hand can be seen\nin Figure 7.2. Here, only the maximum of SRB and O-SII bu\u010f\u0179er is taken into account;\nnot both requirements.55 The smallest capital charge totals 6.3% of credit RWA. The\ncorresponding bank reports nearly three times as much CET1 as required by the model.56\nThe highest capital charge in terms of credit RWA totals 27.2%; the corresponding bank\nreported nearly 8pps less CET1 capital than the suggested combined model-based capital\ncharge for credit risk. Four other banks, labeled bank 2, 3, 4 and 7 in the \u010f\u0179gure, also\nreported less capital than our maximum model-based charge, the di\u010f\u0179erence being 96, 14,\n50 and 9pps, respectively. Therefore, our results emphasize that the distribution of capital\namong the banks might not be consistent with a macroprudential risk assessment.\n\nFurther research. We also do not consider the following capital instruments:\nthe capital conservation bu\u010f\u0179er, the counter-cyclical capital bu\u010f\u0179er and the bu\u010f\u0179er for global systemically\nimportant institutions.\n\n\nFigure 7.3: Banks grouped with respect to their expected shortfall contributions\n\n(a) Banks\u00e2 average share in the system\u00e2s ES\n\n(b) Four groups of respective O-SII bu\u010f\u0179ers\n\nNote: Four groups of banks are shown, clustered according to their mean ES contributions (i.e. percentage\nshares in the expected shortfall of the system) using the k-means algorithms. Source: National Institute\u00e2s Global Econometric Model (NiGEM), International\nMonetary Fund, World Bank, National Central Banks, Deutsche Bundesbank (German credit register\nand supervisory reporting system), the authors\u00e2 own calculations and stochastic simulations.\n\nfor future research: a network extension to the credit risk model that will incorporate di-\nrect and indirect contagion through the interbank exposure and asset \u010f\u0179re sales; dynamic\nprojections of bank balance sheets and income statements; market and operational risk\nmodels. Moreover, in tandem with a capital stress test, liquidity bu\u010f\u0179ers should be chal-\nlenged by funding shocks in order to assess the overall resilience of the system (see Hirtle\nand Lehnert, 2014, p. 8). Most importantly, a comprehensive macroprudential approach\nto stress testing needs to include the feedback e\u010f\u0179ects of a possible credit contraction and\nasset reallocation on the real economy. Obviously, the output risk metrics of an extended\nmodeling framework will be di\u010f\u0179erent in numbers from those presented in the paper. This\nwill not, however, a\u010f\u0179ect the logic of the coherent approach to capital adequacy assessment\nfrom the micro- and macroprudential perspective which we propose.\n\n8 Conclusions\n\nThis paper develops an advanced portfolio model for credit risk assessment in a bank-\ning sector called SystemicCreditRisk and embeds it into a novel stress testing framework\nwhich can inform decisions on micro- and macroprudential capital requirements under\nsystemic stress with focus on credit risk: M-PRESS-CreditRisk. From a technical point\nof view we add to the literature by developing a detailed dependence structure (copula)\nthat can capture the externality of tail risk, i.e. risk of extreme losses that materialize only\n\n\nfrom di\u010f\u0179erent industry sectors and countries in a non-linear way. This approach accounts\nfor many simultaneous borrower defaults across banks\u00e2 portfolios and, therefore, incorpo-\nrates credit default concentration risk in a banking system. Consequently, portfolio loss\ndistributions of individual banks and the entire system show a higher likelihood of large\nlosses. In comparison with Basel II and similar approaches based on simplifying assump-\ntions of perfectly diversi\u010f\u0179ed portfolios, no concentration risk, linear dependencies, absence\nof clustering borrower defaults and banks that are independent from each other (no sys-\ntemic risk), our model considerably reduces the scope for the possible underestimation of\ncredit risk in the banking system.\n\nAdditionally to the SystemicCreditRisk model, M-PRESS-CreditRisk consists of the\nmodule that generates multi-risk-factor, multi-country stress scenarios designed for our\napplication in NiGEM and the satellite macro-econometric model that helps to translate\nthese scenarios into the credit portfolio model. As to the policy applications, we show how\nthe risk metrics derived from the combination of the portfolio model and scenario analysis\ncan inform supervisors\u00e2 judgment about the level of capital needed in the banking system\nto cover both expected and unexpected losses under normal and adverse macroeconomic\nconditions (baseline and stress scenarios, respectively). To this end, the framework pro-\nvides model-based measures of both bank-level and systemic credit risk that supervisors\nmay use in their assessment of the whole chain of capital adequacy: starting with dynamic\nloan loss provisioning, proceeding with minimum capital requirements, including Pillar 2\nadd-ons, and \u010f\u0179nishing with macroprudential bu\u010f\u0179ers that address structural systemic risk.\nWe also illustrate how the framework may be put into practice, using a sample of 12\nsystemically important German banks and utilizing a baseline and three stress scenarios\n(oil crisis, \u010f\u0179nancial crisis, and \u010f\u0179scal contraction). Based on the results, we argue that the\nactual capital levels and the capital needs calculated with additional regard to systemic\ncredit risk may di\u010f\u0179er considerably. Moreover, although the aggregate capital \u010f\u0179gures\nsuggest that there is enough capital in the system as a whole to withstand severe adverse\nmacroeconomic scenarios, the analysis on the bank level indicates that the distribution of\ncapital in the banking system might be suboptimal from a systemic point of view. This\nfollows from the observation that a number of banks show excess capital compared to\nthe overall requirement calibrated to the systemic risk metrics from our model, whereas\nanother banks\u00e2 capital base needs improvement.\nIn the worst case, \u010f\u0179ve banks would\nhave di\u010f\u0179culties satisfying the combined model-based micro- and macroprudential capital\nrequirements.\n\nAt the end, we must emphasize that our numerical results should be treated with\ncaution because our model is subject to a number of constraints. First, it only focuses on\ncredit risk, whereas regulatory requirements also address other risk sources such as market\nand operational risk. Second, our model concentrates on only one channel of systemic risk\npropagation represented by the correlated bank exposures; contagion among the banks or\nother second-round e\u010f\u0179ects are not considered here. Finally, M-PRESS-CreditRisk links a\nnumber of approaches together which introduces an additional layer of model risk.\n\nBearing these caveats in mind, the risk measures generated in the coherent stress\ntesting framework of M-PRESS-CreditRisk may help supervisors think of di\u010f\u0179erent micro-\nand macroprudential capital instruments as a logically linked chain of requirements and\nsupport the calibration of bank-speci\u010f\u0179c capital charges.\n\n\nReferences\n\nAas, K. Then, the normalized\ngamma variable Y := X/E[X] has unity expectation, and its distribution function can be\ndescribed using only the variance: var(Y ) = var(X)/E[X] = 1/k = \u00ce\u0105.\n\n\nA.2 Basics of copulas\n\nA comprehensive introduction to the copula theory may be found in Nelsen (1999); Joe\n(1997). The gist of the copula concept can be explained in a few paragraphs, though.\nConsider a joint cumulative distribution function (cdf) of a random vector. This comprises\ninformation about each single random variable and information about the interdependen-\ncies between the random variables. We can separate these two pieces of information in a\nformal way. That is, each joint cdf can be expressed in terms of its univariate marginal\ndistributions and a unique function \u00e2 called copula \u00e2 that describes its dependence struc-\nture. The Sklar\u00e2s theorem formalizes this idea (for proof see, for instance, Nelsen, 1999,\n\nTheorem A.1 (Sklar )\n\nLet H be a continuous joint cdf of a random vector (X1, . . . , XN ) with univariate\nmarginal cdfs FXi with i = 1, . . . , N . There exists a unique copula function C :\n[0, 1]N (cid:55)\u00e2 [0, 1] such as for all xi \u00e2 R\u00e2\u015e{\u00e2\u00e2,\u00e2} with i = 1, . . . , N the following holds\n\nH(x1, . . . , xN ) = C(cid:0)FX1(x1), . . . , FXN (xN )(cid:1).\n\nThe converse is also true: given a copula C :\nFXi with i = 1, . . . , N the function H in Equation (A.2) is an N -dimensional cdf with\nunivariate margins FX1, . . . , FXN .\n\nA copula itself is a joint cdf on the N -dimensional unit hypercube. It has uniform mar-\ngins that represent the cdfs of the probability-integral transforms of the original random\nvariables given by U := FX(X):\n\nC(u1, . . . , uN ) = H(cid:0)F \u00e21\n\n\n(uN )(cid:1),\n\n\nXN\n\n\nA copula is invariant under strictly monotone transformations of the random variables.\nThe same is true of copula-based dependence measures. We de\u010f\u0179ne two such (bivariate)\nmeasures: Kendall\u00e2s rank correlation and coe\u010f\u0179cient of tail dependence.\n\nDe\u010f\u0179nition A.1 (Kendall\u00e2s rank correlation)\n\nLet (X1, Y1) and (X2, Y2) be two iid random vectors. Then Kendall\u00e2s rank correlation,\ndenoted \u010e , is given by\n\n\n\nThe \u010f\u0179rst term in Equation (A.3) is the probability of concordance of the two random\nvectors. The second term is the probability of discordance.\n\nThe invariance of Kendall\u00e2s \u010e to transformations of the marginals is an advantage\nover the Pearson\u00e2s product-moment correlation. The Pearson\u00e2s \u010e only describes the linear\nrelationship between variables; it measures how well the random variables cluster around a\nlinear function. Therefore, \u010e is a natural measure of association for multivariate normally\nand, more generally, elliptically distributed random variables. For other multivariate\ndistributions, measures of concordance like \u010e are more appropriate because they are more\ngeneral and re\u010f\u0179ect the degree to which random variables cluster around a monotone\n\n\nfunction (with linear functions being only one of the special cases).\n\nDe\u010f\u0179nition A.2 (Coe\u010f\u0179cients of tail dependence)\n\n\n\n\n(u)(cid:9)\n(u)(cid:9) ,\n\nLet X1 and X2 be random variables with cdfs FX1 and FX2. The coe\u010f\u0179cients of upper\nand lower tail dependence of X1 and X2, denoted \u00ce\u0165U and \u00ce\u0165L, respectively, are\n\n\u00ce\u0165U = lim\n\u00ce\u0165L = lim\n\nprovided that limits \u00ce\u0165U , \u00ce\u0165L \u00e2 [0, 1] exist.\nIf \u00ce\u0165(\u00c2\u02c7) \u00e2\u013d 0, X1 and X2 are said to be\nasymptotically dependent (in the corresponding tail). If \u00ce\u0165(\u00c2\u02c7) = 0, X1 and X2 are said\nto be asymptotically independent (in the corresponding tail).\n\n\n\n\n\nAccording to de\u010f\u0179nition A.2, extreme realizations of two asymptotically tail-dependent\nrandom variables tend to occur simultaneously. By the same token, asymptotical inde-\npendence in the tails means that, regardless of whether two random variables are linearly\ncorrelated or not, extreme realizations occur independently for each variable.\n\nOften, using copulas to construct multivariate models with desirable dependence prop-\nerties is more convenient than specifying cdfs. It is especially true if a copula, but not\nthe corresponding cdf, can be expressed in the form of a simple formula. Copulas of one\nspecial class \u00e2 Archimedean copulas \u00e2 have particulary simple analytical representation\nin terms of what is known as a generating function, denoted \u010e, and the general inverse of\nthe generating function, denoted \u010e\u00e21:\n\nC(u1, . . . , uN ) = \u010e\u00e21(cid:0)\u010e(u1) + \u00c2\u02c7\u00c2\u02c7\u00c2\u02c7 + \u010e(uN )(cid:1).\n\n\nTo give rise to a proper Archimedean copula, a generating function must satisfy certain\n\nArchimedean copulas have a number of appealing features that make them popular\nin \u010f\u0179nance and risk management. Their simple analytical representation facilitates their\nuse in high-dimensional portfolio models. These copulas are \u010f\u0179exible in capturing various\ndependence structures, including tail dependence, which makes them suitable for modeling\nextreme events. For a number of families of Archimedean copulas, e\u010f\u0179cient sampling\nalgorithms have been developed, too.\n\nAt the same time, the permutation symmetry, stemming from the exchangeability of\nthe summands in Equation (A.6), constrains the practical applicability of Archimedean\ncopulas. The permutation symmetry means that the dependence among all components\nis identical; all sub-copulas of the same dimension are equal. For those models, where\nthe exchangeability of the marginals poses too strong a restriction, a more general and\n\u010f\u0179exible class of nested Archimedean copulas should be considered.\n\nNested Archimedean copulas are often called hierarchical Archimedean copulas, or\nHACs. A HAC represents a hierarchical structure of sub-copulas, where di\u010f\u0179erent sub-\ncopulas may be de\u010f\u0179ned for separate groups of marginals. For instance, a copula with \u010f\u0179ve\n57The inverse of the generator function must be (at least) N -monotone on the interval [0,\u00e2). This\nis why Laplace transforms of positive random variables, being completely monotone functions, are often\napplied to construct Archimedean copulas.\n\n\narguments and a structure of sub-copulas schematically represented as (((1, 2), 3), (4, 5))\ntakes the following form:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nThis is a partially nested HAC with three sub-copulas: one sub-copula is a fully nested\nHAC that joins arguments 1, 2 and 3; other two sub-copulas are the regular two-dimensional\nArchimedean copulas that join 1 with 2 and 4 with 5, respectively.\n\nA HAC can adopt arbitrarily elaborate structures. It may be either fully or partially\nnested. The generator functions within a HAC can come either from di\u010f\u0179erent generator\nfamilies or from just a single generator family with di\u010f\u0179erent parameters for its sub-copulas.\nIn this paper, we construct a HAC making use of the generator function of the Gumbel\nfamily of Archimedean copulas.\n\nIn what follows we consider, without loss of generality, the two-dimensional Gumbel\ncopula. This copula exhibits asymmetric dependence structure by putting more proba-\nbility mass on the upper tail. Its generating function is given by \u010e(u) = (\u00e2 ln(u))\u00ce\u00b8 and\nthe bivariate copula function reads\n\n\nC Gu\n\n\u00ce\u00b8\n\n\nParameter 1 \u00e2\u00a4 \u00ce\u00b8 < \u00e2 controls the degree of dependence between two random variables.\nFor \u00ce\u00b8 = 1 the variables are independent; they become perfectly dependent as \u00ce\u00b8 grows\nlarge. For any \u00ce\u00b8 > 1, the random variables joined by a Gumbel copula are positively\nassociated and asymptotically dependent in the upper tail. For a Gumbel copula, the\npopulation versions of Kendall\u00e2s tau is given by \u010e Gu = (\u00ce\u00b8 \u00e2 1)/\u00ce\u00b8 and the coe\u010f\u0179cient of\nU = 2 \u00e2 21/\u00ce\u00b8. The lower tail dependence coe\u010f\u0179cient\nupper tail dependence is given by \u00ce\u0165Gu\nis zero.\n\n.\n\nAs to the copula estimation, the \u00e2HAC package\u00e2 in R programming environment\ndocumented in Okhrin and Ristig (2012) provides a multi-stage MLE procedure, which\nsimultaneously determines the parameter and the structure of a HAC. The algorithm\nendows the estimator with the usual asymptotic properties and is less computationally\nintensive than a regular one-step MLE. It can be summarized as follows: Consider M\nrandom variables. For all possible pairs of these variables, parameters \u00ce\u00b8 of bivariate\nGumbel copulas are estimated using regular MLE. The pair with the strongest dependence\n(the largest \u00ce\u00b8) is then combined by its estimated copula to a new pseudo variable \u00e2 the\n\u010f\u0179rst node in the copula hierarchy. The program reiterates the whole procedure until all\nM\u00e21 parameters of bivariate copula nodes are estimated. To allow for more sophisticated\nstructures, the variables of two successive nodes are aggregated if the di\u010f\u0179erence between\ncorresponding parameters \u00ce\u00b8 is smaller than a \u010f\u0179xed small threshold which we set to 0.5.\nThis allows for marginal copulas with more than two arguments. The chosen value of 0.5\nmakes it possible to neglect small di\u010f\u0179erences in the strength of dependence, preserving\na reasonably granular copula structure. For further information on the methods and\nchallenges of estimating Archimedean copulas in high dimensions, we refer the reader to\n\n\nA.3 Details on approximation of EADs, LGDs and PDs\n\nIf a bank has more than one credit exposures to a particular borrower, the EAD equals the\ntotal exposure to this borrower. The on-balance sheet exposure is taken at its book value.\nBy contrast, lenders convert their o\u010f\u0179-balance sheet exposure stemming from derivatives\ninto credit equivalents using appropriate credit conversion factors. They report other\no\u010f\u0179-balance sheet credit exposure such as \u00e2guarantees extended\u00e2 at its book value.\n\nTo compute LGD, we take into account the following information about credit risk\nmitigation techniques: (i) collateral posted by the borrower and (ii) guarantees provided\nby other banks. For the secured (overcollateralized) part of the exposure we assign the\nLGD of 35%. For the remaining unsecured part we \u010f\u0179x the LGD at 45% (see sections 287\nand 295 in BCBS, 2006). As for the guarantees, we scale down the LGD for that part\nof the exposure for which a guarantee is available by the ratio of the guarantor\u00e2s PD to\nthe borrower\u00e2s PD. Ideally, simulation of a double default, i.e. a possible default of the\nguarantor given the default of the borrower, should be performed. But this is di\u010f\u0179cult\nto implement because no estimates for the probability of joint default of the borrower-\nguarantor pairs are available. Thus, we only model the borrowers\u00e2s default, but scale\ndown the corresponding LGD to account for the risk mitigation technique (see sections\nto the guarantor (g) should be equal to the expected loss from the secured exposure to\nthe borrower (b): LGDg \u00c2\u02c7 P Dg = LGDb \u00c2\u02c7 P Db. Then, we compute the adjusted LGD\nas LGDb = LGDg \u00c2\u02c7 P Dg/P Db, with LGDg = 45% if P Dg < P Db. If, on the contrary,\nP Dg > P Db, we do not consider the guarantee at all (see section 301 in BCBS, 2006). If\nan exposure is backed by more than one guarantor, the median guarantors\u00e2 PD is taken.\nFor the credit exposures backed by both collateral and a guarantee, we take both into\naccount subject to the LGD \u010f\u0179oor of 0%.\n\nThe PDs are taken as reported by the lenders. They originate from the lenders\u00e2\ninternal rating systems. For a given rating system, the PDs of two borrowers only di\u010f\u0179er\nfrom each other if the borrowers belong to di\u010f\u0179erent rating categories. For all PDs we\nA few reported PDs that exceed this ceiling are set to 100%, which means a sure default of\nthe borrower. The same borrowers may be rated di\u010f\u0179erently by di\u010f\u0179erent banks. Therefore,\nif multiple PDs are available for the same borrower, we take the maximum value. For\nborrowers for which no estimates of PDs are available at all, we take the median PD of all\nborrowers belonging to the same group (sector/country/region). As an exception, missing\nPDs for banks are set to the median PD for the banking sector across all countries.\n\n\nA.4 Tables and \u010f\u0179gures\n\nTable A.1: Descriptive statistics for the 12 systemically important German banks\n\nVariable\n\nAmount (ebillion or %)\n\nNumber of banks\nTotal assets\nPercentage of total assets of all German banks\nTotal credit exposure from the credit register\nTotal RWA\nTotal RWA: credit risk\nTotal RWA: credit register\nTotal capital\nTotal CET1 capital\nTotal CET1 to total RWA ratio\n\n\nNote: Data as of 2013Q4.
